content.title: Venous Hemodynamics
content.description: The physiologic principles governing venous blood flow, pressure dynamics, and the factors that promote venous return in health and disease.
content.definition: Venous hemodynamics describes the low-pressure, high-capacitance system that returns blood to the heart. Key determinants include venous pressure gradients, respiratory variation, muscle pump function, venous valves, and the effects of gravity. Understanding these principles is essential for diagnosing and treating venous disease.

pressure_dynamics: Resting venous pressure in foot: 80-90 mmHg (standing)
Ambulatory venous pressure: Falls to 20-30 mmHg with walking
Venous pressure gradient drives return to heart
venous_return_mechanisms: Respiratory pump: Diaphragm descent creates negative intrathoracic pressure
Muscle pump: Calf and thigh muscle contraction compresses veins
Arterial pulsation: Adjacent arteries compress veins
Cardiac suction: Atrial relaxation creates negative pressure
Gravity: Above heart level, gravity aids return
valve_function: Prevent retrograde flow during muscle relaxation
Segment venous column to reduce hydrostatic pressure
Valve failure leads to venous hypertension
pathophysiologic_consequences: Reflux: Valve incompetence causes retrograde flow
Obstruction: Thrombus or compression impedes antegrade flow
Muscle pump failure: Immobility, obesity, weakness
All lead to ambulatory venous hypertension

learning_objectives: Describe venous pressure dynamics in standing and walking
Understand valve function in venous hemodynamics
Connect hemodynamic failure to clinical venous disease
clinical_pearls: Normal ambulatory venous pressure drops 50-60% with walking
Failure to drop indicates reflux, obstruction, or pump failure
Air plethysmography quantifies venous hemodynamics non-invasively
Venous filling time <20 seconds indicates significant reflux
The calf muscle pump is often called the 'peripheral heart'
